Expectation1: Follow safety and hygiene protocols at all times.
Situation1: They are expected to strictly follow all safety rules, such as using gloves, masks, and proper sanitizers for every task.
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: The station is set to lock its doors in ten minutes.
Story: I glanced at the clock on the break room wall, my gloved hands still damp from scrubbing the restroom sinks. My shift wasn’t over, but the polling station would close in ten minutes. I’d promised myself I wouldn’t miss voting this year. But the supervisor had just reminded us—no shortcuts, no exceptions. Every surface had to be sanitized, gloves and masks on, every protocol followed. If I left now, I’d have to rush, maybe skip a few steps, maybe even take off my gloves early to save time. But if I stayed and finished properly, I’d miss my chance to vote. My heart pounded as I weighed the rules drilled into me at work against my responsibility as a citizen. I could almost hear my mother’s voice: “Your vote matters.” But I could also hear my supervisor: “One mistake, and you’re out.” My hands shook as I stared at the clock, torn between two worlds, both demanding something I wasn’t sure I could give.
